there is no true true large scale "random" i believe. there will always be a subset of something that can be narrowed out or guaranteed to make it not fully "random".  even if in theory we had a way to 100% randomly generate a number that would for sure be 100% random, no questions asked, then that still isn't "fully random" because anything that is not a number isn't possible.  so yes, individual things, and even events up to a certain scale can indeed be "random", at the largest scales or in general, i don't think there can be a "random".  even if you say that every single possible everything we know of could happen in our universe, even that is constrained by a lot of things we know cannot or will not happen.

Nothing can move faster than the speed of light relative to anything else. Something cannot move through "space", it can only move relative to something else. Due to time differences, two things can be moving away from you at near c in opposite directions, but only be moving slightly nearer c away from each other. Nothing can ever move away from you faster than c.

I guess, for the black hole question, if you could cross the event horizon and then a miracle happens permitting you to escape, you would probably live to see the heat death of the universe (or whatever the universe's ultimate fate is to be). Time dilation becomes infinite at the event horizon, right? So it would seem (when we allow for this miracle) that all of time would pass outside the event horizon in the briefest of moments spent inside it.

Many factual issues with this video and most of popular science:

1) There's no black holes; they're a mathematical reification. All the simulation and models of them are conjecture yet perpetuated as if they were real. Again there's no direct empirical evidence for them, and it's only assumed that these mystical entities are responsible for cosmic structures, when well known electrical engineering principles can explain them all fully without invoking any imaginary nonsense.

2) All discussion on universe expanding and what ramifications that has are pure speculation, as the expansion model itself is based on elements like redshift signifying distance or speed (as a doppler effect), which are not empirically tested and proven.

3) There is no randomness in the universe, both field theory and the use or "erasers" in quantum mechanics prove it so. Logically, randomness makes no sense anyway, in a system that functions purely on direct interactions between fields. The "uncertainty principle" is a dangerous misunderstanding in QM in regards to the difficulty in measuring the effects of the atomic realm when approaching it from particle logic. The uncertainty principle is the issue where your observational tool interferes with the experiment itself - this was perpetuated via the double slit experiment, which is actually incorrectly reviewed. I, and many others have reproduced the laser experiments, to discover it can have the interference pattern with a single slit, or even around a sewing needle. When elaborating the experiment and using the erasers, you can bypass the supposed "neutralization of interference" which made people believe in particle-wave duality, and gain a result that's not only predictable, but measurable and has no randomness.

Laser light is coherent light, and known from holography art, that when split is can create a fractal effect in which every part of the image contains the whole image: this is called incommensurability. In quantum they call that entanglement, or spooky action at a distance where a split laser beam exhibits "entangled particles" that react to one another. The reality, they are coherent in of the same field; a laser is a light-resonant system.

About the universe being flat, it's kind of a half-truth. We cannot discern with our current experimental capabilities if the universe is flat, because we only have access to a very small portion of the universe as reference. If we are talking about flatness for anything experimental, then yes, the universe is assumed to be flat. But the actual geometry of the universe could be literally anything, from a flat membrane to a sphere to a taurus. The main problem is that we only "see" 4 dimensions, and we only "see" as far as the speed of light and age of the universe lets us see. In order to be able to observe any curvature in the first 4 dimensions (x, y, z and time), you would need to be able to observe it from a 5th dimensional perspective. Picture a perfect sphere the size of the Earth, and then picture a single ant on that sphere. Could the ant ever see that the sphere is actually a sphere?

Ther reason that the universe seems to be expanding at almost the speed of light is that it isn't. During the travel period of most photons they are able to pick up and lose energy (check up on gravity lensing). In doing this they shift their spectral signature due to the increase of photonic energy. In other words the red and blue shift of photonic energy associated with light cannot be used as a guide to the speed of any cosmological body, be it a planet or a galactic mass. Due to interaction with planets, stars and even black holes, the photons can and do increase energy levels which will cause a spectral shift towards the blue. As the photons move away from planets, stars and even black holes, they move away under the gravity effect of the body's and will subsequently exhibit a shift towards the red because the photons are under the gravity effect and use up more of their energy than when they are being attracted by gravity. This effect is ignored by most cosmologists and causes problems like insufficient calculated matter in the cosmos to cause closure. Excessive expansion of the cosmos and lastly the need for dark matter and dark energy, which in actuality do not exist, except as a reason for the scientists to believe that they haven't made a colossal error. Imagine the cosmos with all it's matter expanding at the speed of light. Imagine also making a calculation of the total amount of matter in the universe and achieving a 95% error and attributing that error to the existence of DARK MATTER and DARK ENERGY. I ask you! Believe what you will, but please not everything the scientists tell you. If you do then you might as well believe in bogy men as well.
Regards to all and sundry MoK

At 4 minutes... According to my understanding of relativity no two objects can ever move faster than light relative to each other. When it gets to that point we will be able to measure them moving at light speed even though a third party standing between the two objects will measure both objects moving away from each other at light speed. The third party would see them moving apart at a cumulative speed of 2c, but an observer on either object would still be able to measure the other at c. Well, except that the light still wouldn't reach the two observers because they'd be receding at light speed and so they couldn't actually observe each other at all, but the principal holds true if they're both receding at .9c and are able to observe each other. The third part would see them with moving apart at 1.8c, but they'd still see each other moving away from themselves at no faster than c.

Randomness is only an illusion. Or, rather, a perspective. The inner workings of a system/entity/organism may very well seem and be random when viewing from the smaller scale (ie. in both size and time) perspective. But there are forces which pervade this randomness; forces that cause and drive this randomness. And this random occurrence of events, at the larger scale, come together to fashion a coherent image/pattern/system. So from the perspective of the larger scale, it looks like the inner workings of the system are specifically purposed to allow the system to exist/function. To give a visual description I borrow from Deepak Chopra - picture a moving image on a tv screen. its very coherent: sharp lines and groups of colours within those lines; all coming together to produce a specific shape that is very much alive. Zoom in on this motion picture to its fundamental building blocks. At this smaller scale, what you see is not a coherent picture, but rather, a random pattern of firing photons; Colours being fired at random. "Photons fire in the cosmos for the same reason they fire in a tv: to produce a picture". Just as the mind uses thinking to organize reality to make sense, the universe does so physically; somehow arranging random events so that they are meaningful. Randomness and Coordinateness are two sides to the same coin.

Hmm.  If you could move at an "infinite" speed.  Would you seem to be moving at all?  Since "Infinite" is the gathering of all possible (and impossible) outcomes at once (Referring to the other factor in addition to it, as infinite has no value on it's own).  You'd be going every speed at the same time including impossible speeds.  "Negative Speeds".  As well as completely absent of acceleration in it's entirety.  By deffinition it's impossible. 

But the what ifs?  These are what breed innovation.  The finding of new truths.  "The person who has made no mistakes has never tried anything new." and such.  Impossibilities of the 80s are already realities of today.  Don't question the dreamers.  The skeptics. The thinkers.  Stating something as a fact can be changed in a mere moment.  50 years proven "True" don't change the possibility that some little kid some day might put toys together in such a way that unimaginally will change science forever.  But how can we tell?  We only live today.  (Example to show point if hard to understand base statement.) 

Even death can't be proven as a concrete factor in some mindsets.  Time is seen differently per individual.  So on so forth.  There is no such thing as a constant until we no longer exist.  We will always find something new.  Something smaller.  Or bigger.  Everything is relative.  Yes?  No?  Who can say?  We all think differently.  So no use arguing.

To actually answer the question, from an observer's view, after seeing the frozen image of the person who crossed the event horizon redshift into nonexistence, right once that person leaves that section of the black hole's gravity well, the person would appear to rematerialize at the speed of light. Viewing it at a slow pace, it would almost look like the opposite of redshifting, as the first rays of light to hit the person once back beyond that dreadful point of no return, would scatter the light back to the viewer, with the red light taking the longest to reach him/her. Blueshifting, perhaps? It's also quite possible that light, coming so close to that point of a black hole which can stop it in it's track, would be quite slow in reaching the viewer, in which case the effects described would be compounded, and there's likely to be some blurring, which would decrease as the person gets further out of the black hole.

Anyway, from the view of the person escaping that point in the gravity well, I can't exactly say. There are lot of theories on the subject of what it looks like going in, and I can only imagine it would look pretty much the same while leaving, only in reverse.

If you entered the event horizon of a black hole but just before you hit the singularity (and for arguments sake you make the greatest escape in the history of existence, escaping something that even light cannot escape) and you take that magical jet pack and fly out of it. What would happen? As an extension of the question, would it be possible to catch a person within the event horizon going towards the singularity if you got between the person and the singularity, opened up your spaceship door, and catch something that all of our senses tell us does not exist? You fly in, you fly out, but due to light being unable to escape the black hole, I would only be able to see you flying into the event horizon then stop moving. If I were outside the black hole, would I see your exit of the event horizon? and if so would I see a temporary picture of yourself flying into the black hole and then another flying out? To make the question simpler, imagine a 5 foot around funnel shaped black hole floating in the middle of your kitchen. if the pouring end of the funnel is the event horizon, and the smallest hole at the end of the funnel was the singularity, if you reached inside with your arm and just before you touched the singularity you pulled your arm out, what would that look like? Would you see your arm both inside the black hole and on your body like normal? (pretend like your arm didn't get destroyed.)

I learned something else about the purple sky thing. Apparently it isn't purple because the photo pigments in the back of our eyes aren't biologically inclined to see the violet light due to the absorbance spectra. The cones in our eyes are not being excited by this violet light  but are more so with blue. They sky is emitting blue-ish/violet wavelengths but we just are genetically predisposed to not see the shorter violet wavelengths.

On another note... Stars have been witnessed to break the gravitational pull of a black hole's event horizon... it doesn't happen often, but it can happen. It's usually because one star falls in but at the same time gets attracted to another star that is already in the event horizon but hasn't fallen into the black hole yet. This can happen to binary stars as well.

My understanding is that space is a 3D 'area' which we can move around in etc, like a 3D graph: you can map the co-ordinates. Meanwhile space-time is 4D. The same idea applies between 3D space and 4D spacetime.

In a sense, yes. While it is true that relativity forbids velocities greater than the speed of light in a vacuum, light doesn't always travel at that speed. This phenomenon is analogous to the sonic boom we experience when an object travels at speeds faster than the speed of sound.

Think about it.

We once synchronized two atomic clocks on earth and sent one to orbit the earth in a satellite, and another to stay on earth. The one in space lost time due to the faster speed traveled compared to the relatively stationary earth. Therefore, the one in space traveled into the future at a slightly faster rate than the one on earth. Today, we have to make up for this time lost in our calculations when we use GPS satellites, since they tell us the time difference between sent and incoming signals.

Infinity is not a made up word. It is a real concept. As are real numbers (and with that, imaginary numbers also). Randomness is just a term used to describe a probabalistic system where outcomes are impossible to predict, but often possible to predict in the long run (opposed to chaotic systems, which are possible to model but in the long run diverge too much). What exoplanetomega told you is not correct. Black holes are the natural mathematical solution to GR equations under certain conditions, so BHs are consistent while GR does not violate conservation principles (see Hawking's works). The actual flaw is that GR has not yet been "translated" to quantum scales, which is what we need in order to treat with gravitational singularities. Singularities are an expected breakdown of the theory, in the same way that Newton's laws are expected to fail at v~c.

And to be more precise: Black isn't actually the absence of light, but rather a contrast to more light around it. Depends how you define color. Colors from a light source (sun, monitor) are combined "additively", meaning that the whole spectrum combined together will produce white and, yes, the absence of any light will produce black.

But the colors we deal with in the real world are mostly added "substractively", because they are surfaces that reflect only certain wavelengths, absorbing the others. In this case (e.g. mixing water colors), black would be adding all colors together so all light is absorbed.
